title: Tanganyicia rufofilosa
text:
Tanganyicia rufofilosa is a species of <a href="tropical">tropical</a> <a href="freshwater%20snail">freshwater snail</a> with an <a href="operculum%20%28gastropod%29">operculum</a>, an <a href="Aquatic%20animal">aquatic</a> <a href="gastropod">gastropod</a> <a href="mollusk">mollusk</a> in the family <a href="Paludomidae">Paludomidae</a>.
Before 2002, this species was placed within the family <a href="Thiaridae">Thiaridae</a>.
Distribution.
"Tanganyicia rufofilosa" is <a href="endemic">endemic</a> to <a href="Lake%20Tanganyika">Lake Tanganyika</a>. It is found in <a href="Burundi">Burundi</a>, the <a href="Democratic%20Republic%20of%20the%20Congo">Democratic Republic of the Congo</a>, <a href="Tanzania">Tanzania</a>, and <a href="Zambia">Zambia</a>. The <a href="type%20locality%20%28biology%29">type locality</a> is Lake Tanganyika.
Description.
The shape of the <a href="gastropod%20shell">shell</a> is ovate conic.
The width of the shell is ; the height of the shell is .
Ecology.
The natural <a href="habitat">habitat</a> of this snail is freshwater <a href="lake">lake</a>s. "Tanganyicia rufofilosa" lives in depths on silty and sandy bottoms, in high population densities.
The females are <a href="viviparous">viviparous</a>.
In 1996, this was considered an Endangered Species. Its survival is threatened mainly by <a href="sedimentation">sedimentation</a>. The habitats of this species are damaged by settlements and other disturbances.
